title: Stock Futures Wobble Amid Wave of Bank Reports; Twitter shares jumped after Elon Musk disclosed an offer to take the company private
text:
Twitter shares rose 7% premarket after Tesla Chief Executive Elon Musk—who already holds a more than 9% stake in the social-media firm—disclosed an offer to buy the company outright in a deal valuing it at more than $43 billion. Tesla fell 1.5%.

Wells Fargo shares fell more than 3% in premarket trading after the bank reported a drop in first-quarter earnings. Morgan Stanley gained 3% after reporting a drop in revenue that was less than analysts had been expecting. Goldman Sachs rose 2% after reporting earnings per share which beat forecasts.

Big U.S. banks are expected to suffer from comparisons to bumper profits during the pandemic. Analysts expect first-quarter earnings for S&P 500 banks fell 37% from a year ago, according to FactSet.

UnitedHealth Group rose 0.7% after the health insurer said profits beat expectations and lifted its guidance.

Corporate results will also be scrutinized for guidance on how companies expect to manage tighter policy from the Federal Reserve, with a series of interest-rate increases expected.

"Investors are trying to figure out if the Fed is on the right course. Can they stick the landing in terms of bringing inflation down without bringing the economy down?" said David Donabedian, chief investment officer at CIBC Private Wealth.

The yield on the 10-year U.S. Treasury note edged down to 2.661% from 2.688% on Wednesday. While wavering in recent days, the yield on the benchmark note earlier this week hit its highest level since January 2019 as investors gear up for rising interest rates. Bond yields and prices move in opposite directions.

Retail sales figures for March and weekly jobless claims are due at 8:30 a.m. ET. The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index is due at 10 a.m.

In commodity markets, Brent crude, the international oil benchmark, fell 1.4% to $107.29 a barrel. Gold prices declined 0.2%.

Overseas, the Stoxx Europe 600 inched up 0.4% as gains for travel stocks balanced losses for telecommunication firms. Sweden's Ericsson dropped 5% after reporting earnings that missed expectations in part because it suspended its operations in Russia.

In Asia, stock markets were mostly higher. Japan's Nikkei 225 rose 1.2%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 0.7% and the Shanghai Composite Index gained 1.2%.

Write to Will Horner at william.horner@wsj.com

Stock Futures Wobble Amid Wave of Bank Reports
